p: In the same year, Lee and coworkers characterized the presence of 7-isopentenyloxycoumarin in five Isocoma spp. (Asteraceae) native to southwestern United Stated and northern Mexico, namely Isocoma pluriflora (Torr. and A. Gray) Greene, commonly known as “southern goldenbush”, Isocoma tenuisecta Greene, “burrow goldenweed”, Isocoma azteca G. L. Nesom, “aztech goldenbush”, Isocoma acradenia (Greene) Greene, “alkali goldenbush”, and finally Isocoma rusbyi Greene, “Rusby’s goldenbush”. All these plants are poisonous and cause trembles in livestock, although it may be that such a toxicity does not relate to the presence of the title compound. 7-Isopentenyloxycoumarin was detected in amounts ranging from 0.07 µg/mg of dry extract to 1.1 µg/mg and was not found in I. pluriflora and I. azteca [ 17]. Furthermore, for the Isocoma genus, the one described by Lee and coworkers is the first report on the isolation and structural characterization of an oxyprenylated coumarin.
